contents.title: Presumed conspicuous - The New Inquiry
contents.description_html: In this post about zero-sum validation games in social media, Freddie deBoer expresses his frustration with people's refusal to let other people just like what they like. Even our purely subjective aesthetic choices are not allowed to be our own anymore.
contents.description: In this post about zero-sum validation games in social media, Freddie deBoer expresses his frustration with people's refusal to let other people just like what they like. Even our purely subjective aesthetic choices are not allowed to be our own anymore.

source.title: Presumed conspicuous - The New Inquiry

contents.title: Beyond Terrordome - The New Inquiry
contents.description_html: It's obvious that Facebook wants to be the ultimate ad-targeting mechanism: It collects information on self-generated demographic networks and is developing ways to sell those micro-demos to marketers looking to maximize the effectiveness of their messaging.
contents.description: It's obvious that Facebook wants to be the ultimate ad-targeting mechanism: It collects information on self-generated demographic networks and is developing ways to sell those micro-demos to marketers looking to maximize the effectiveness of their messaging.

source.title: Beyond Terrordome - The New Inquiry

contents.title: Computer Love
contents.description_html: Looking back at Star Trek: The Next Generation on its 25th anniversary By Brian Phillips on We had orange carpet in our living room in Oklahoma where, on regular weeknights, I would stay up, semi-religiously, and watch Star Trek: The Next Generation, usually instead of doing my algebra homework.
contents.description: Looking back at Star Trek: The Next Generation on its 25th anniversary By Brian Phillips on We had orange carpet in our living room in Oklahoma where, on regular weeknights, I would stay up, semi-religiously, and watch Star Trek: The Next Generation, usually instead of doing my algebra homework.

source.title: Computer Love

contents.title: The Post-Apocalyptic Tech Scene
contents.description_html: I spent the last week traveling around the Rust Belt talking with startups and entrepreneurs. We spent time in incubators and accelerators, in co-working spaces and rehabbed manufacturing complexes. As I wandered through the post-industrial landscape, I kept recalling something that author and farmer Novella Carpenter said at a panel she did with my wife at the San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association a couple months back.
contents.description: I spent the last week traveling around the Rust Belt talking with startups and entrepreneurs. We spent time in incubators and accelerators, in co-working spaces and rehabbed manufacturing complexes. As I wandered through the post-industrial landscape, I kept recalling something that author and farmer Novella Carpenter said at a panel she did with my wife at the San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association a couple months back.

source.title: The Post-Apocalyptic Tech Scene

contents.title: Digital Vertigo: How Today's Online Social Revolution Is Dividing, Diminishing, and Disorienting Us
contents.generated_title: Digital Vertigo: How Today's Online Social Revolution Is Dividing, Diminishing, and Disorienting Us
contents.description_html: "Unlike most commentators, Andrew Keen observes the internet as if from a distance. Digital Vertigo may be one of the few books on the subject that, twenty years from now, will be seen to have got it right. Neither blinkered advocate nor hardened cynic, he identifies the good and the bad with a rare human and historical perspective.
contents.description: "Unlike most commentators, Andrew Keen observes the internet as if from a distance. Digital Vertigo may be one of the few books on the subject that, twenty years from now, will be seen to have got it right. Neither blinkered advocate nor hardened cynic, he identifies the good and the bad with a rare human and historical perspective.

source.title: Digital Vertigo: How Today's Online Social Revolution Is Dividing, Diminishing, and Disorienting Us

contents.title: The Condition: Chronic Self-Disclosure
contents.description_html: A decade ago, the internet's signature feature was obfuscation. You could invent a new identity; embellish your life to make it that much more interesting; buff out the imperfections; or just hide without feeling like an anti-social creep for it. Message boards, chat rooms, and nascent blogs, all depended on a technology-induced veil, a curtain that shielded online actions.
contents.description: A decade ago, the internet's signature feature was obfuscation. You could invent a new identity; embellish your life to make it that much more interesting; buff out the imperfections; or just hide without feeling like an anti-social creep for it. Message boards, chat rooms, and nascent blogs, all depended on a technology-induced veil, a curtain that shielded online actions.

source.title: The Condition: Chronic Self-Disclosure

contents.title: Facebook as experiment - The New Inquiry
contents.generated_title: Facebook as experiment - The New Inquiry
contents.description_html: When I was in high school, I worked for a while at a market-research firm. My job was to cold-call people out of the phone book and ask them questions about cat litter, cigarettes, laundry detergents, and other products, depending on whatever clients the firm had at the time.
contents.description: When I was in high school, I worked for a while at a market-research firm. My job was to cold-call people out of the phone book and ask them questions about cat litter, cigarettes, laundry detergents, and other products, depending on whatever clients the firm had at the time.

source.title: Facebook as experiment - The New Inquiry

contents.title: Welcome to the Future Nauseous
contents.description_html: Email This Post Print This Post Both science fiction and futurism seem to miss an important piece of how the future actually turns into the present. They fail to capture the way we don't seem to notice when the future actually arrives.
contents.description: Email This Post Print This Post Both science fiction and futurism seem to miss an important piece of how the future actually turns into the present. They fail to capture the way we don't seem to notice when the future actually arrives.

contents.title: The Last Psychiatrist: The Second Story Of Echo And Narcissus
contents.generated_title: The Last Psychiatrist: The Second Story Of Echo And Narcissus
contents.description_html: Are you listening closely? This is the story you know: "Narcissus was a man who was so in love with himself that he fell in love with his own reflection. No one else was good enough for him. He stared into the pool, and eventually wasted away." But that's not the whole story.
contents.description: Are you listening closely? This is the story you know: "Narcissus was a man who was so in love with himself that he fell in love with his own reflection. No one else was good enough for him. He stared into the pool, and eventually wasted away." But that's not the whole story.

source.title: The Last Psychiatrist: The Second Story Of Echo And Narcissus

contents.title: Loving the Alien - The New Inquiry
contents.generated_title: Loving the Alien - The New Inquiry
contents.description_html: Socialist economist Jacques Attali's 1977 book Noise: A Political Economy of Music (translated in 1984 by Brian Massumi) offered a structuralist "political economy of music." In the U.S., this explicitly political analysis of music made a splash in "new" or critical musicology, which was then in its infancy.
contents.description: Socialist economist Jacques Attali's 1977 book Noise: A Political Economy of Music (translated in 1984 by Brian Massumi) offered a structuralist "political economy of music." In the U.S., this explicitly political analysis of music made a splash in "new" or critical musicology, which was then in its infancy.

source.title: Loving the Alien - The New Inquiry

contents.title: Comfortably Alone - The New Inquiry
contents.description_html: Social media puts an end to shyness by generalizing its pathology As a shy person, I've believed for most of my life that being among new people required an elaborate social disguise, one that would allow me to feel both present and absent, noticed and unnoticed.
contents.description: Social media puts an end to shyness by generalizing its pathology As a shy person, I've believed for most of my life that being among new people required an elaborate social disguise, one that would allow me to feel both present and absent, noticed and unnoticed.

source.title: Comfortably Alone - The New Inquiry

contents.title: The Paranoid-Critical Method - The New Inquiry
contents.generated_title: The Paranoid-Critical Method - The New Inquiry
contents.description_html: Paranoia, as the cliché has it, is a higher state of awareness, a form of privileged insight unburdened by such trivialities as plausibility or verification. It's sometimes seen as a cancer that afflicts our hermeneutical faculty, causing it to enlarge and impose itself everywhere, explaining everything in terms of everything else in an ongoing, provisional way, usually to simultaneously rationalize and vitiate a sense of futility.
contents.description: Paranoia, as the cliché has it, is a higher state of awareness, a form of privileged insight unburdened by such trivialities as plausibility or verification. It's sometimes seen as a cancer that afflicts our hermeneutical faculty, causing it to enlarge and impose itself everywhere, explaining everything in terms of everything else in an ongoing, provisional way, usually to simultaneously rationalize and vitiate a sense of futility.

source.title: The Paranoid-Critical Method - The New Inquiry

contents.title: The Accidental Bricoleurs
contents.description_html: Like fast fashion, social media have brought with them a profusion of means and ways to reshape and display our identity. Constantly given new tools to share with, always prompted to say something new about ourselves ("What's on your mind?" Facebook asks thoughtfully), we are pressured to continually devise ingenious solutions to our identity.
contents.description: Like fast fashion, social media have brought with them a profusion of means and ways to reshape and display our identity. Constantly given new tools to share with, always prompted to say something new about ourselves ("What's on your mind?" Facebook asks thoughtfully), we are pressured to continually devise ingenious solutions to our identity.

source.title: The Accidental Bricoleurs

contents.title: A New Privacy pt. I: Distributed Agency & the Myth of Autonomy " Cyborgology
contents.generated_title: A New Privacy pt. I: Distributed Agency & the Myth of Autonomy " Cyborgology
contents.description_html: Last month at TtW2012, a panel titled " Logging off and Disconnection" considered how and why some people choose to restrict (or even terminate) their participation in digital social life-and in doing so raised the question, is it truly possible to log off?
contents.description: Last month at TtW2012, a panel titled " Logging off and Disconnection" considered how and why some people choose to restrict (or even terminate) their participation in digital social life-and in doing so raised the question, is it truly possible to log off?

source.title: A New Privacy pt. I: Distributed Agency & the Myth of Autonomy " Cyborgology

contents.description: Posted: October 30, 2012 at 1:00 pm | By: Larissa Hildebrandt | Tags: terms of service, ToS;DR; crowdsourcing; privacy policy; online privacy We've all done it: We're signing up for a new online service and we lie that we've read and agree to the terms and conditions.

contents.title: Invasion of the cyber hustlers
contents.description_html: Jeff Jarvis, Clay Shirky, Jay Rosen - the internet age has seen the rise of a class of gurus intent on "disrupting" old-fashioned practices like asking us to pay for valuable content. Meanwhile, web giants like Google and Apple jealously guard their profitable secrets. Why should we listen to these self-appointed prophets of the future?
contents.description: Jeff Jarvis, Clay Shirky, Jay Rosen - the internet age has seen the rise of a class of gurus intent on "disrupting" old-fashioned practices like asking us to pay for valuable content. Meanwhile, web giants like Google and Apple jealously guard their profitable secrets. Why should we listen to these self-appointed prophets of the future?

source.title: Invasion of the cyber hustlers

contents.title: What Turned Jaron Lanier Against the Web?
contents.generated_title: What Turned Jaron Lanier Against the Web?
contents.description_html: Jaron Lanier was one of the creators of our current digital reality and now he wants to subvert the web before it engulfs us all. (Robert Holmgren) I couldn't help thinking of John Le Carré's spy novels as I awaited my rendezvous with Jaron Lanier in a corner of the lobby of the stylish W Hotel just off Union Square in Manhattan.
contents.description: Jaron Lanier was one of the creators of our current digital reality and now he wants to subvert the web before it engulfs us all. (Robert Holmgren) I couldn't help thinking of John Le Carré's spy novels as I awaited my rendezvous with Jaron Lanier in a corner of the lobby of the stylish W Hotel just off Union Square in Manhattan.

source.title: What Turned Jaron Lanier Against the Web?

contents.title: Generation Why? by Zadie Smith | The New York Review of Books
contents.generated_title: Generation Why? by Zadie Smith | The New York Review of Books
contents.description_html: The Social Network a film directed by David Fincher, with a screenplay by Aaron Sorkin You Are Not a Gadget: A Manifesto by Jaron Lanier Knopf, 209 pp., $24.95 How long is a generation these days? I must be in Mark Zuckerberg's generation-there are only nine years between us-but somehow it doesn't feel that way.
contents.description: The Social Network a film directed by David Fincher, with a screenplay by Aaron Sorkin You Are Not a Gadget: A Manifesto by Jaron Lanier Knopf, 209 pp., $24.95 How long is a generation these days? I must be in Mark Zuckerberg's generation-there are only nine years between us-but somehow it doesn't feel that way.

source.title: Generation Why? by Zadie Smith | The New York Review of Books

metadata.description:
Csaba Osvath is a doctoral candidate at the University of South Florida, pursuing literacy studies with a special focus on qualitative methods and arts based research. His research explores the epistemological and pedagogical roles/functions of artmaking in the context of literacy education. His current project is the creation of a mixed media collage technique and a methodological artistic process for knowledge acquisition and knowledge production in educational settings. Csaba grew up and studied theology and horticulture in Hungary, prior to his graduate studies and service as an artist and educator in the United States. 

https://csabaosvath.wordpress.com/

Transfer your open channels to me.
(Transfers approved by the Are.na Team)

contents.description_html: Jaron Lanier was one of the creators of our current digital reality and now he wants to subvert the web before it engulfs us all. (Robert Holmgren) I couldn't help thinking of John Le Carré's spy novels as I awaited my rendezvous with Jaron Lanier in a corner of the lobby of the stylish W Hotel just off Union Square in Manhattan.
contents.description: Jaron Lanier was one of the creators of our current digital reality and now he wants to subvert the web before it engulfs us all. source.title: What Turned Jaron Lanier Against the Web?

contents.description_html: The Social Network a film directed by David Fincher, with a screenplay by Aaron Sorkin You Are Not a Gadget: A Manifesto by Jaron Lanier Knopf, 209 pp., $24.95 How long is a generation these days? I must be in Mark Zuckerberg's generation-there are only nine years between us-but somehow it doesn't feel that way.

metadata.description:
Csaba Osvath is a doctoral candidate at the University of South Florida, pursuing literacy studies with a special focus on qualitative methods and arts based research. His research explores the epistemological and pedagogical roles/functions of artmaking in the context of literacy education. His current project is the creation of a mixed media collage technique and a methodological artistic process for knowledge acquisition and knowledge production in educational settings. Csaba grew up and studied theology and horticulture in Hungary, prior to his graduate studies and service as an artist and educator in the United States. 

https://csabaosvath.wordpress.com/
